awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multilevel Methods for Optimal Control of Partial Differential Equations and Optimization-Based Domain Decomposition
awd_abstract_narration:
Optimal control of differential equations (PDECO) plays an important role in an ever increasing number of real-life applications ranging from petroleum reservoir modeling to weather prediction and the optimal shape design of airplane wings. While traditional PDECO uses deterministic models, this project targets PDECO where the differential equations also include uncertainties, such as irregular fluctuations in the ground composition, or turbulent wind speeds. The ultimate aim is to dramatically improve the solution quality and the computing time of such optimal control problems. The novel algorithms resulted from this project will impact optimization problems arising in geophysics, weather modeling etc. These problems are generic and advances in solution techniques will also benefit other sciences. Open source software will be created and shared with the community. Four graduate students will benefit from the project. Special attention will be given to recruit students from underrepresented groups. 


The project is focused on developing robust, scalable multilevel solvers for mainly two classes of potentially large-scale PDECO problems: PDECOs constrained by stochastic partial differential equations (PDEs) and by nonlocal PDEs. An additional thrust is to develop multilevel solvers in support of optimization-based domain decomposition - another kind of PDECO - for the forward PDE-models themselves. Multilevel/multigrid solvers are known to be optimal for many classes of forward models. However, their application to solve PDECO problems is still in its infancy. A naive application of multilevel methods to solve such optimization problems can lead to dependence on resolution (mesh-dependence) and on other parameters of the problem such as the stochastic dimension or the number of subdomains. In addition, since each iterate involves at least one PDE solve, the cost of solving such optimization problems can be prohibitive for large-scale, high-resolution problems, especially for problems that are significantly more expensive than the traditional, deterministic ones. The algorithms developed in this project aim to set new standards of efficiency and robustness.  Novel mathematical tools will further advance the knowledge in numerical analysis and optimization. New special topics courses will be developed based on the research generated in the project and the notes will be shared with the community. The results of the research will be actively disseminated via technical research papers and talks at national and international conferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The aims of the collaborative between George Mason University (GMU) and the University of Maryland, Baltimore County (UMBC) were to develop highly efficient and scalable multilevel algorithms for the optimal control of several classes of partial differential equations (PDEs); these classes include fractional PDEs and PDEs with uncertainty, as well as multilevel methods for optimization-based solvers of certain PDEs. While optimal control of PDEs (PDECO) is a powerful tool for parameter identification in PDEs and other continuous models of physical phenomena, a major challenge remains the potentially very high cost of the PDECO solution process. Multigrid/multilevel methods (MGMs) have been used for many decades as efficient solvers for PDEs, but their usage in PDECO is still under development, and has not been widely adopted. The purpose of this project was to significantly expand the class of PDECO problems for which Multigrid/multilevel methods are highly efficient.

The UMBC team has taken on the following tasks: 1. Developing MGMs for PDECO of PDEs with uncertain coefficients; 2. Contributing to the development MGMs for PDECO of fractional PDEs elliptic equations; 3.  Developing MGMs for optimization-based domain decomposition for elliptic equations; 4. Training of PhD students.

Intellectual merit: Novel MGMs have been developed for PDECO of elliptic PDEs with uncertain coefficients, both using stochastic collocation (SC) and stochastic Galerkin (SG) for the discretization of the stochastic component; the new methods are not only highly efficient, but also robust with respect to the discretization parameters (polynomial degree for SG and number of quadrature points for SC). Newly developed MGMs for PDECO of fractional elliptic PDEs also proved to be highly efficient and robust with respect to the fractional powers. MGMs for PDECO were also show to be highly efficient for optimization-based domain decomposition of elliptic PDEs. Novel methods were applied successfully to PDECO of the Stokes-Brinkman system. Several other SG-based methods were developed for stability analysis of the Navier-Stokes system with uncertain viscosity and for nonlinear elasticity. New efficient MGMs were also developed for PDECO of parabolic equations, and MGMs were also extended to algebraic multigrid.

Broader impacts: Efficient MGMs methods for PDECO problems open new opportunities for their wider adoption for applications in fluid dynamics, geophysics, weather modeling, and material science, all of these being areas where stochastic and fractional models have been playing increasingly important roles. The novel methods opened new research directions on efficient solvers for PDECO for larger classes of continuous models and optimization-based model coupling.

Three PhD theses resulted from the project and nine papers were published, with several more in preparation. PI, in collaboration with PI at GMU has co-organized a conference at UMBC, and also co-organized a virtual seminar. PI and co-PI gave over ten talks at various conferences and seminars.
